Jim,

I always thought that with photography where it is
today, a great beginner book would be on tekketsu
and/or iron of tsuba.  Also maybe there is another
place to host pictures like RichT? (Isn't that nice of
me to volunteer Rich's site).  The only reason I say
this is just like there are sites where you can look
up the pattern of steel for sword to kantei, why
couldn't we do the same with the pics of tsuba just as
you have done.  I know not all tsuba have them, but
still would help peg down school.  SO many projects
out there.  Anyway, thanks again.
Ken

--- Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:

> Ken,
> Good, glad it helped.  I plan to update the photos
> on my site and will include images of rims where
> there is something to see.  Given storage and
> bandwidth limitations I will probably have to get
> rid of the pieces that I don't have any longer so
> that I can focus on the best examples.  
> 
> The technical aspects of tekkotsu are far from
> settled.  The quote that Pete posted from the
> Solingen catalog is an interesting one.  I don't
> know whether that is how tekkotsu were formed in the
> Muromachi period.  I have read hypotheses crediting
> everything from the source of the ore onward for
> being the cause of tekkotsu.  There is even an idea
> that the bones were not even visible in the original
> piece but are only revealed over time due to the
> corrosion and/or wear resistance of the higher
> carbon regions.  I doubt that that's entirely true,
> but it is a factor for guards with condition
> problems -- the tekkotsu will stand out.
> 
> Jim
> 
> 
> 
>   Jim,
> 
>   Excellent, while of course I would love to handle
>   them,  these pictures are the next best thing. 
> Great
>   stuff and makes it clearer.  If someone had the
> time,
>   it would be great to put these up on
> your/someone's
>   website.  All these sites devoted to swords, could
> use
>   some more to tsuba.  Would love to see tekkotsu
>   website depicting various schools.
> 
>   Now for the next question- why so different? 
> metal
>   used? folding techniques?  when forming the mimi
> what
>   steps would they do (I know big questions)?
> 
>   Thanks- as always you are extremely helpful.
>   Ken
